content: you reference PGP, Thunderbird does not use PGP as Linux users understand it, it maintains it's own key database. See https://support.mozilla.org/kb/introduction-to-e2e-encryption#w_how-to-use-openpgp-end-to-end-encryption-with-thunderbird
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Sorry for the potentially bad wording. I'm using the integrated Thunderbird key database/encryption feature. However, it seems the UI for Linux differs from the one in MacOS such as I'm not able to decrypt messages in Thunderbird for Linux. See the screenshots above for reference.
creator: thomas_runge

content: Plenty of MUAs (such as Thunderbird) don’t handle inline pgp when it’s inside a HTML document, which is what happens when you hand paste a PGP message block into most webmail systems. That’s why people keep saying “I couldn’t read your email until I hit reply”, because if you have replies set to plain text by default it renders the plaintext version of the original mail in the compose window, which is then correctly parsed - but not before. So tell the sender of the troubled encrypted messages to use PGP/MIME. Why this works on the Mac I have no idea.
creator: christ1

content: I'm afraid that's not too helpful. In this case, the sender is a corporate user who doesn't have much influence on what their mail backend is doing in regards of e-mail encryption. From my perspective the point here is actually why TB Linux cannot handle it the way TB MacOS does. - In fact, TB Windows is working even better by simply showing the decrypted message, instead of asking the user to press a button...
creator: thomas_runge

content: It shouldn't be too hard to send inline PGP encrypted messages in plain text, instead of HTML.
creator: christ1

content: I almost don't dare say it, but that's exactly the problem with e-mail encryption. The sender doesn't want to/shouldn't have to worry about a particular mail client being able to handle the encryption method. The system should just work. And if, as in this case, one and the same mail client(!), in this case Thunderbird 115, displays/handles the encrypted mail differently on three different operating systems, then I understand why the encryption of e-mails simply doesn't catch on...
creator: thomas_runge

content:
BTW: Plain text instead of HTML did not help in TB on Linux. Did not make any difference in TB/Linux or TB/MacOS.

Actually, the issue seems to be even worse with encrypted attachments, as these don't get decrypted on forwarding or replying. In fact, I haven't found a way to decrypt attachments in TB/Linux at all. In TB/MacOS one can right-click and decrypt, but that doesn't work in TB/Linux...

In Folder Pane. the accounts 'Sent' folder should store sent emails. That 'Sent' folder may be called 'Sent Mail' or 'Sent Items' etc If a pop account it will be called 'Sent'. If an imap account it usually uses whatever is the name used by the server eg: 'Sent' or 'Sent Mail' or 'Sent Items' etc

In Account Settings Select 'Copies & Folders' for the account Typically the following is selected:

Select checkbox: 'Place a copy in' If pop account select 'Sent folder on' and choose same pop account. If imap account select 'Other' and choose eg: 'Sent on pop account name'

creator: TKK

content:
TKK said

Matt said
That is a message from your mail provider that you have been a bad boy and they have put you in timeout. Why? I have no idea. Perhaps ask them. I would hazard a guess, as it clears quickly, that you are sending to much mail to comply with their terms of service so they are enforcing their TOS but that is only a guess.

As clearly as I could state it, at the very same time that this happens, I am able to send the same emails to the same recipients from the mail provider's service directly, so it is logical to assume it is not a restriction imposed from the mail provider, am I right in thinking so?

Unfortunately folk think that using their providers website to send mail offers some diagnostic value. It does not. Providers are very careful with their webmail, they have convinced more than 80% of their customers to use these services and usually get a load of advertising at the same time. For the remaining 20% the server used to send mail is rarely if ever the same one used to send mail from the website. This is compounded by many having completely different rules about mail volumes and sizes for SMTP V's Webmail. With the SMTP rout always having the most restrictive offerings and rules.

To reiterate, this is coming from the SMTP server. I have no information that would indicate if you are using even the correct SMTP server. I often see folk trying to send email using a Gmail SMTP server for an email address that has nothing to do with gmail or Google. They have weird issues as well.

To quote the message "the mail server said" that actually says the message originated with the server you have connected to. By the very nature of the message it is not coming from Thunderbird, despite it being the delivery mechanism. Ask your provider what the problem is, and when they say you can send from webmail so everything is Ok disagree with them and insist they support their SMTP server messages.

I did do a google search on the actual error badmailFrom list and that would indicate that the email address of mail server is marked as sending spam by the recipient server. That is the server at abv.bg is refusing delivery. But irrespective if it is your mail provider of your recipients, that does not change the fact that it is not an error that Thunderbird is issuing, it is one it to being given to deliver.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
that part of the message is weird. That looks? like an IPV6 internet address which is "unknown" in DNS in so much as it has no name "unknown". But it is the port that is truly weird. 51018

The IP address appears to resolve to a city of Ville in France. But I have no idea what could be using Port 51018 as it is not assigned to any "normal" protocol. It is a dynamic port that I would guess could be used for a VPN internally, or a proxy in a public wifi situation.

My guess is you are trying to send mail from an IP address your service provider does not allow for that purpose.

content: You're trying to send from a non-free.fr account through the free.fr smtp server, which might not be allowed unless you add the non-free.fr account as an allowed sender in the free.fr webmail settings. Most services don't allow the sending account to send through an smtp with a different User Name (email address), even if they're on the same domain.

To add your free.fr email address to your messaging service (application or software: Outlook, Gmail, Apple Mail, Thunderbird, etc.), you will need the following information:

Outgoing server

Incoming server

content:
S PP said
Thanks. I updated to the latest version of Thunderbird but still cannot send email. I should probably find an alternative to Thunderbird as suddenly it isn't working for me. Shame.

Let me walk you back to your previous comment which answers your inability to send email.

S PP said
Please note I have a domain name for my emails. Have tried ports 587, 465 and 25 for outgoing mail, unsuccessfully. I can receive mail but not send. This problem occurred around two weeks ago although I have made no changes to settings.
  1. You have a domain name for your emails;
  2. Where is the domain hosted?
  3. What SMTP server comes with the hosting package?
  4. Why are you not using it to send mail for your domain?

You should be using the SMTP server provided by your web hosting provider, not SMTP.free.fr

Odd as it may seem, you will be getting tangled in anti spam tools that prohibit the use of relays to send mail. Such mail routinely fails DMARC, SPF and other anti spam policy frameworks

You are relaying mail for your domain via the Free.fr servers. Free.fr has probably found themselves blacklisted with other major providers for allowing that and have changed policies.

5. Have you configured free.fr as a permitted sender in the MX record in DNS for your domain?

I really can not comment with details from free.fr however because their website offers one of the worst support experiences I have ever been involved with. Information is dumbed down as to be useless, is mostly incomplete and navigating in a language other than french is not for the feint-hearted.

content:
The problem with many proprietary backups is that they backup while Thunderbird is running, virtually guaranteeing a backup that will not restore. Assuming that is not your problem, do this:

  1. locate the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder in the backup
  2. be sure that thunderbird is not running but is installed
  3. in windows file explorer, locate the c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming folder and paste your thunderbird folder there. you will be prompted to overwrite whatever is there. Allow that.
  4. now, start thunderbird, if the profile is not corrupt thunderbird should start ok.

content:
install Thunderbird open thunderbird and navigate to the open folder button in the troubleshooting information. Close Thunderbird once the windows file explorer opens in your current profile.

Now copy the contents of the original profile into the new one, replacing all files like prefs.js. Make sure the copy includes sub folders. I have seen lots of folks that do that copy and end up with only the files in the folder not the entire profile. I assume they don't know about Ctrl+A to select all before they copy anything. Yet others copy the p4rofile folder into the existing profile folder so it is a sub folder of the new profile. Again this will not work. So unless you are prompted to replace files you did something wrong. Strop and work it out.

Restart Thunderbird and it should "just be there"

content:
Won't comment on your typo (maybe not a typo) of the last word :) . If you are getting multiple profiles from your backup there is one folder for each one - I have only ever had 1 profiles.ini. running linux. Can you locate your current profiles.ini file on your computer? I know tbird auto-creates a brand new profile on upgrades and makes it the default without so much as a neveryourmind leaving your old one in place. You may want to do your own editing of the .ini file on your computer using notepad. AFAIK all your profiles will show in one .ini file . The structure is awkward but fairly well documented on line. Do you know which profile folder is last known good one? Its important to get that name and save it. Each profile has its own folder bearing the profile name within the folder holding the .ini. It can be confusing at first but may give you insights into the issue. If you get to this point you may delete the unneeded and keep your own. Mine is in a folder named gj6azsgx.default and looks like this: 

       [Profile0]

Name=default IsRelative=1 Path=gj6azsgx.default Default=1

[General] StartWithLastProfile=1 Version=2

[InstallFD621D5DEBA8CC6A] Default=gj6azsgx.default

I think the last 2 lines are informational - hope this helps...
creator: jeff.g.group

content:
The people who answer questions here, for the most part, are other users volunteering their time (like me), not Mozilla employees or developers. This means we have no access to your system to check anything, we can only work with you to help you fix your own problem based on the information you provide. Details of mail provider and the exact messages you see raised by the software are critical for this process to succeed.

If you want to leave feedback for developers, you can go to the Firefox Help menu and select Share ideas and feedback…. Alternatively, you can use this link. Your feedback gets collected by a team of people who read it and gather data about the most common issues.

You can also file a bug report or feature request. See File a bug report or feature request for Mozilla products for details.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The easiest way is to copy the entire profile. Those steps are here:

BACKUP from old PC

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE to new PC

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there

BUT From your post, it appears you are using an older version. Is the version on new PC the same? If not, the safest conversion would be to install the same version on new PC. That would ensure total compatibility.

ALTERNATE APPROACH

Okay, if you don't want to do that, and just import the message folders, you can do this: - exit thunderbird - in windows file explorer, locate the Local Folders folder of old profile and copy the message folders (but not the msf files) to the Local Folders folder on new PC - if the account is POP, the account needs to have already been installed on new PC. Copying the message folders will overlay any messages you have already downloaded. If that isn't an issue, locate the Mail\<accountname> folder on old PC and copy everything there to same location on new PC.

creator: christ1

content:
christ1 said
Check with your email provider about password recovery options.

Harry,

It appears that you marked this response as "unhelpful". If you were to more information here, which might be able to help.


See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb and https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password

Be aware if Thunderbird just started asking for your password it is unlikely it "forgot" but that connection to the sever using the password is has was rejected. It may have deleted the password after multiple failed attempts (and clicking cancel on the request for a password), but I really don't recall a time when it actually "forgot". That would require a rather serious bug.

Also, some requests for a password mean you have a security product/antivirus that has messed up post an update resulting in no mail. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-receive-messages

If you solved this, posting your results might help someone else.

content:
re :I'm trying to set up an identical IMAP account on a laptop PC

You have not mentioned whether you have set up all the requirements to access a gmail account. The server settings are ok. Only you will know if the User name email address and password are correct, but they would be the same as used to access webmail account via a browser.

You also do not mention whether you have downloaded an installation from the official website or via awindows app store. Personally, I would advise you get it from the official website as windows app store puts profile where you do not expect it. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

You need to check all the following before trying to create the mail account.

1. Check Firewall

Exit Thunderbird Access Firewall - maybe it's the default that comes with laptop or controlled by any Anti-Virus you installed. Thunderbird program nust be set up as an allowed program. Please confirm Thunderbird is set up as an allowed app in the Firewall.

2. VPN Please double check you are not using a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products also offer VPN and some people have discovered it was auto enabled. Switch it off or create a split tunnelling option and allow thunderbird to use it.

3. Do you have any program using the localhost ? Some people manage their own websites and may use a program to faciliate this such as Apache Xampp If yes, then you must switch it off until you have set up the oauth token and Thunderbird has the account working ok.

4. Check cookies are enabled/allowed. In Thunderbird

  • Settings > Privacy & Securiy
  • Web Content
  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • 'Accept third party cookies' 'Always
  • Click on 'Exceptions' button
  • Add this: https://accounts.google.com
  • Set status as 'Allow'
  • click on 'Save Changes'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thanks to both of you who responded. The problem turns out to a very different one from what I described. Here's what I think has happened:

Google has been making a transition away from allowing anyone to access a gmail.com account using an IMAP password-based connection. Since the beginning of 2025 they require use of the Oauth2 password-free protocol.

Here's the catch: Setting up an Oauth2 connection now requires having a Google Workspace Account. I say "now" because when I set up the gmail account on my desktop PC for use with Word's mailmerge-via-Outlook, there was a loophole for folks like me who don't have (or want) a Google Workspace Account. I was able to jump through the hoops to set up a Google Workspace Sync for Microsoft Outlook (GWSMO) without actually having an account.

But in the new year, when I tried to set up the same connection on my laptop, that door was closed.

Sorry to put you through the effort to answer my original question, but your answers did in fact help me narrow down where the problem is. Thank you!
creator: natbarn

content: There is no magic combination of server settings. Nor is there a point trying arbitrary combinations of settings. Use the settings required by your email provider. If in doubt check their support web site/forum or ask their support.
creator: christ1

content:
Wow this ee.net mob must still be living in the 20th Century. I hope they are charging like the are.

I have all sorts of questions that I would like to address to their technical department, but I am sure they would be insulted. They are probably one of perhaps a dozen mail providers on the planet that does not use encrypted connections. Google have been doing their best to eliminate them for a long time now.

However I digress.

based on the information here https://www.ee.net/netscapesetup.php

Settings are Server mail.ee.net For POP port is 110 For IMAP it is 143 For SMTP 25.

All with no connection encryption and using the password transmitted insecurely.


I did a test https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/mail.ee.net/Hkj3IlJd/ on port 110 and hat indicated that the server does in fact support an encrypted connection using TLS so you should be able to use SSL/TLS connection security.

I did a further test on the correct modern encrypted port of 995 and it was answered by a POP3 secure server. So I though lets try encrypted SMTP on Port 587. See https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/email-security/smtp-port-25-587/

That test also appears to be successful as does the IMAP encrypted port. https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/mail.ee.net/KkWWnEZw/

So I would suggest you try, despite your provider saying something very different

Server mail.ee.net For POP port is 995 with SSL/TLS For IMAP it is 993 with SSL/TLS For SMTP 587 wiith SSL/TLS

Make sure you also disable any antivirus email scanning and for the setup process try disabling any antivirus other than windows defender. They are often the problem rather than being a solution.

BTW I have recently seen folk who only retain settings until Thunderbird is restarted. Their antivirus blocks the writing of the prefs.js file on shutdown to changes are just lost. Other have contention issues caused by scanning in the profile folder leading to backup file being written with a number and again the result is changes are lost, unless you know to go looking for the numbered file and rename it. So no scanning in the profile folder while Thunderbird is running.

content:
My suggestion is that you are several releases behind and updating may fix the issues. I do acknowledge there may be some quick fixes, but the upgrade path is safest. This is because THunderbird updates and changes the environment sometimes and it does that on the first version of each release. So, for you, there are many releases between 45 and 136 (or 127). The textbook approach would be to install the 0.1. version of each release in sequence, as that will update your profile appropriately. Here is a list of the series: 

https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/releases/   If you are missing data, I suggest starting over. That is,

- install 45 on the new machine and then do this. Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
  9. continue with the above-suggested upgrade path. Prior versions are at https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/
creator: davidsk

content:
Windows has supported the use of Ctrl and Shift modifiers for mouse click actions since version 3 that I am aware of. It may have been earlier, but that is where my serious involvement started.

Click on a message, Hold shift and click on another and everything is selected between and including the clicks. Hold Alt and click on one of the selected messages and it and only it will be deselected. Click it again to reselect it Continuing with alt, click a non selected message and it will be selected.

Patrick O'Neill said
then hit delete.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Oh and I forgot Ctrl+A which will select everything in the list.
